moves.1. d4: This game was very complex. I was heavily challenged and was lucky to claw my way to a draw against a higher-rated opponent.
moves.1... d5 2. Nc3: An immediate attempt to throw me off. I was expecting the Queen's Gambit.
moves.2... Nf6 3. Nf3 e6: With my center secured, I now have to develop my pieces.
moves.6. e4 O-O: Always castle early if you can...  I realize White can advance his e-pawn, but I would rather secure my King than worry about my Bishop being driven.
moves.7. e5 Be7 8. Bd3 c5: Time to try and gain Queen-side space, as White controls more territory on the King-side.
moves.9. dxc5 Bxc5: White decides to let me free up my Bishop.
moves.10. O-O Nc6 11. Na4 Be7: I could have given back the minor exchange and activated my Queen with 11... Bb6 12 Nxb6 Qxb6. I didn't feel activating my Queen was worth it.
moves.12. c3 Bd7 13. b4: White attempts to seize Queen-side space.
moves.13... Rc8: I counter by attempting to pressure the exposed, backward c-pawn.
moves.14. Re1 Nb8: Now my Rook aims down the c-file at the pawn.
moves.15. b5 a6: I want to get rid of White's advanced b-pawn.
moves.16. Rb1 axb5 17. Bxb5 Bxb5 18. Rxb5: I'm still up a minor exchange, and White's Pawn-storming attack has been neutralized. But now I have a weak pawn on the b-file. Defense will be a priority.
moves.19... Nd7 20. Rxb7 Rxb7 21. Qxb7: I'm down a Pawn. If I can remove White's passed a-pawn from the board, I feel I can hold the endgame.
moves.21... Nc5 22. Nxc5 Bxc5: The more even exchanges there are, the better my position becomes. If I can have a Bishop vs. a Knight in the endgame, I feel I can easily hold, even down 1 Pawn.
moves.23. Nd4 Qa5: I'm sure not going to exchange minor pieces.
moves.24. Nb3 Qxc3: Material is even. Now to get rid of that obnoxious a-pawn...
moves.25. Rc1: Uh-oh. Now I'm going to be down a piece. Maybe I should have traded minor pieces after all.
moves.25... Qxe5: My Bishop is a goner anyway, so I may as well take the loose Pawn.
moves.26. Nxc5 Qe2: A glimmer of hope. If I can capture that a-pawn and exchange the heavy artillery, I think my 5 Pawns can hold up against Black's 3 Pawns and 1 Knight.
moves.27. a4 Qd2 28. Nb3 Qf4: Still harping on the same theme.
moves.29. Rc8: White fell into the trap! Now I can not only get rid of the a-pawn but also exchange off the Rooks.
moves.30. Rxf8+ Kxf8: Now to exchange off the Queens and coast into a draw.
moves.33. Qb8+ Qe8 34. Qc7 Qe7 35. Qb8+: White can make no progress. I accept the draw offer. A very interesting game.
